modules.comments:
Scene Engine

Tick-based scene orchestration with adapter pattern.

The engine manages transitions between scenes using a three-phase lifecycle:
1. Initialize: Apply init rules to prepare starting state
2. Transition: Interpolate positions from start to target
3. Finalize: Apply final rules and enter stable mode

The engine is generic over the node type. Apps provide an adapter
record with functions that interact with their specific simulation kernel.

Example usage:
```purescript
-- Create adapter for your kernel (D3, WASM, etc.)
adapter = mkAdapter mySimulation

-- Create engine
engineRef <- createEngine adapter

-- Transition to a scene
transitionTo treeFormScene engineRef

-- Call tick from your simulation's tick handler
Sim.onTick (\_ -> tick engineRef) mySimulation
```

declarations.comments: The scene engine, stored in a Ref for mutation across tick callbacks
declarations.title: SceneEngine

declarations.comments: Internal engine state
declarations.title: EngineState

declarations.comments:
Adapter functions that connect the engine to your simulation kernel.

The engine is generic - it doesn't know about D3 or WASM directly.
Instead, you provide these adapter functions that do the actual work.

Each kernel (D3, WASM, etc.) implements `mkAdapter` to create this record.

Example adapter for D3:
```purescript
mkAdapter :: D3Simulation -> EngineAdapter SimNode
mkAdapter sim =
  { getNodes: Sim.getNodes sim
  , capturePositions: \nodes -> Object.fromFoldable $
      map (\n -> Tuple (show n.id) { x: n.x, y: n.y }) nodes
  , interpolatePositions: \start target progress ->
      Sim.interpolatePositionsInPlace start target progress sim
  , updatePositions: \positions ->
      Sim.updatePositionsInPlace positions sim
  , applyRulesInPlace: \rules ->
      applyRulesInPlace_ rules sim.nodes
  , reinitializeForces: reinitForcesFor sim
  , reheat: Sim.reheat sim
  }
```
declarations.title: EngineAdapter

declarations.comments:
Create a new scene engine.

The engine starts with no active scene. Call `transitionTo` to
begin your first scene transition.

Uses default transition duration of ~2 seconds.
declarations.title: createEngine

declarations.comments:
Start a transition to a new scene.

If a transition is already in progress, this is ignored.

The transition lifecycle:
1. Apply scene's `initRules` to prepare starting state
2. Capture current positions as start positions
3. Calculate target positions via scene's `layout` function
4. Begin interpolation (handled by `tick`)
declarations.title: transitionTo

declarations.comments:
Advance the engine by one tick.

Call this from your simulation's tick handler.

Returns `true` if a transition is in progress, `false` if stable.
declarations.title: tick

declarations.comments: Get the current scene configuration (if any).
declarations.title: getCurrentScene

declarations.comments: Check if a transition is in progress.
declarations.title: isTransitioning

declarations.comments:
Get the current transition progress (0.0 to 1.0).

Returns `Nothing` if no transition is in progress.
declarations.title: getTransitionProgress

declarations.comments:
Set the current scene directly (without transition).

Use this when the visualization is already in the target state
(e.g., after initial rendering with pre-computed positions).
declarations.title: setCurrentScene

declarations.comments: Default transition delta: ~2 seconds at 60fps
declarations.title: defaultTransitionDelta

modules.name: Hylograph.Simulation.Core.Engine

declarations.comments:
Runtime state during an active transition.

Tracks the target scene, start/end positions, and current progress.
The interpolation engine updates progress each tick until complete.
Uses tick-based progress (0.0 to 1.0) rather than time-based elapsed.
declarations.title: TransitionState

declarations.comments:
Scene configuration with three-phase lifecycle.

**Phase 1: Initialize** (`initRules`)
Applied before transition starts. Use this to set up starting positions,
e.g., moving tree nodes to the root for a "grow from root" animation.

**Phase 2: Transition** (`layout`)
The interpolation engine smoothly moves nodes from their current positions
to the target positions computed by the layout function.

**Phase 3: Finalize** (`finalRules`)
Applied after transition completes. Use this to set up the stable state,
e.g., unpinning nodes so forces can take over, or setting gridX/gridY.

Example:
```purescript
treeFormScene :: SceneConfig MyNode
treeFormScene =
  { name: "TreeForm"
  , initRules: [ moveToRootRule ]
  , layout: \nodes -> computeTreePositions nodes
  , finalRules: \_ -> [ pinAtTreePositionsRule ]
  , stableMode: Static
  }
```
declarations.title: SceneConfig

declarations.comments:
Position map: node ID (as string) -> position
Used for capturing current positions and specifying targets
declarations.title: PositionMap

declarations.comments:
A rule that selects nodes and applies a transform.

Rules are applied with first-match-wins semantics (like CSS cascade).
If multiple rules match a node, only the first one applies.

Example:
```purescript
pinPackages :: NodeRule MyNode
pinPackages =
  { name: "pinPackages"
  , select: \n -> n.nodeType == Package
  , apply: \n -> n { fx = notNull n.x, fy = notNull n.y }
  }
```
declarations.title: NodeRule

declarations.comments:
Engine mode determines what happens after a transition completes.

- `Physics`: Force simulation runs, nodes settle via forces
- `Static`: Nodes stay pinned at their final positions
declarations.title: EngineMode

modules.comments:
Tick-Driven Transitions

Primitives for animating transitions using simulation ticks rather than CSS.
This is the simulation-aware analog to d3-transition.

Key insight: Force simulations already have a tick loop. We can use that
same loop to drive enter/exit/update animations, giving us:
- Predictable, debuggable behavior
- No CSS timing coordination
- Pure PureScript interpolation

Usage:
```purescript
import Hylograph.Simulation.Core.Tick as T

-- In your state
type State = { entering :: Map String Progress, exiting :: Array (Transitioning Node) }

-- In tick handler
onTick state = do
  let { active: stillEntering } = T.tickProgressMap 0.025 state.entering
  let { active: stillExiting } = T.tickTransitions 0.025 state.exiting
  -- render with interpolated values

-- In render
radius = case enterProgress of
  Just p -> T.lerp 20.0 5.0 (T.easeOut p)
  Nothing -> 5.0
```

declarations.comments: Progress from 0.0 (start) to 1.0 (complete)
declarations.title: Progress

declarations.comments:
Amount to advance progress each tick
At 60fps: 0.025 ≈ 40 ticks ≈ 0.67 seconds
At 60fps: 0.020 ≈ 50 ticks ≈ 0.83 seconds
At 60fps: 0.015 ≈ 67 ticks ≈ 1.1 seconds
declarations.title: TickDelta

declarations.comments: An item in transition, carrying its state and progress
declarations.title: Transitioning

declarations.comments: Easing function: maps linear progress to eased progress
declarations.title: Easing

declarations.comments:
Advance all progress values in a Map, partitioning into active and completed

```purescript
let { active, completed } = tickProgressMap 0.025 enteringNodes
-- active: nodes still animating
-- completed: keys that just finished (for cleanup, callbacks, etc.)
```
declarations.title: tickProgressMap

declarations.comments: Start tracking progress for new keys (from 0.0)
declarations.title: startProgress

declarations.comments: Start tracking progress for new keys from a specific value
declarations.title: startProgressFrom

declarations.comments:
Advance all transitions, partitioning into active and completed

```purescript
let { active, completed } = tickTransitions 0.025 exitingNodes
-- active: items still animating out
-- completed: items that finished (now safe to remove from DOM)
```
declarations.title: tickTransitions

declarations.comments: Wrap items as transitions starting at progress 0.0
declarations.title: startTransitions

declarations.comments: Wrap items as transitions starting at a specific progress
declarations.title: startTransitionsFrom

declarations.comments:
Linear interpolation between two numbers

```purescript
lerp 0.0 100.0 0.5  -- 50.0
lerp 20.0 5.0 1.0   -- 5.0 (shrink from 20 to 5)
```
declarations.title: lerp

declarations.comments: Linear interpolation with progress clamped to [0, 1]
declarations.title: lerpClamped

declarations.comments: Linear interpolation for integers
declarations.title: lerpInt

declarations.comments: No easing (linear)
declarations.title: linear

declarations.comments: Ease in (slow start, fast end) - alias for easeInQuad
declarations.title: easeIn

declarations.comments: Ease out (fast start, slow end) - alias for easeOutQuad
declarations.title: easeOut

declarations.comments: Ease in-out (slow start and end) - alias for easeInOutQuad
declarations.title: easeInOut

declarations.comments: Quadratic ease in: t²
declarations.title: easeInQuad

declarations.comments: Quadratic ease out: 1 - (1-t)²
declarations.title: easeOutQuad

declarations.comments: Quadratic ease in-out
declarations.title: easeInOutQuad

declarations.comments: Cubic ease in: t³
declarations.title: easeInCubic

declarations.comments: Cubic ease out: 1 - (1-t)³
declarations.title: easeOutCubic

declarations.comments: Cubic ease in-out
declarations.title: easeInOutCubic

declarations.comments:
Apply easing to an interpolation function

```purescript
-- Ease-out shrink from 20 to 5
radius = withEasing easeOut (lerp 20.0 5.0) progress
```
declarations.title: withEasing

declarations.comments:
Calculate tick delta for a desired duration at assumed 60fps

```purescript
ticksForDuration 1000  -- 0.0167 (1 second at 60fps)
ticksForDuration 500   -- 0.0333 (0.5 seconds)
```
declarations.title: ticksForDuration

modules.name: Hylograph.Simulation.Core.Tick

modules.comments:
Core Types for Simulation

Kernel-agnostic type definitions for the scene orchestration system.
These types are shared by all kernel implementations (D3, WASM, etc.)

A scene represents a visualization state with:
- A target layout (where nodes should be)
- Rules for initialization and finalization
- A stable mode (physics simulation or static)

declarations.comments: A position in 2D space
declarations.title: Position

declarations.comments:
Position map: node ID (as string) -> position
Used for capturing current positions and specifying targets
declarations.title: PositionMap

declarations.comments:
A rule that selects nodes and applies a transform.

Rules are applied with first-match-wins semantics (like CSS cascade).
If multiple rules match a node, only the first one applies.

Example:
```purescript
pinPackages :: NodeRule MyNode
pinPackages =
  { name: "pinPackages"
  , select: \n -> n.nodeType == Package
  , apply: \n -> n { fx = notNull n.x, fy = notNull n.y }
  }
```
declarations.title: NodeRule

declarations.comments:
Scene configuration with three-phase lifecycle.

**Phase 1: Initialize** (`initRules`)
Applied before transition starts. Use this to set up starting positions,
e.g., moving tree nodes to the root for a "grow from root" animation.

**Phase 2: Transition** (`layout`)
The interpolation engine smoothly moves nodes from their current positions
to the target positions computed by the layout function.

**Phase 3: Finalize** (`finalRules`)
Applied after transition completes. Use this to set up the stable state,
e.g., unpinning nodes so forces can take over, or setting gridX/gridY.

Example:
```purescript
treeFormScene :: SceneConfig MyNode
treeFormScene =
  { name: "TreeForm"
  , initRules: [ moveToRootRule ]
  , layout: \nodes -> computeTreePositions nodes
  , finalRules: \_ -> [ pinAtTreePositionsRule ]
  , stableMode: Static
  }
```
declarations.title: SceneConfig

declarations.comments:
Runtime state during an active transition.

Tracks the target scene, start/end positions, and current progress.
The interpolation engine updates progress each tick until complete.
Uses tick-based progress (0.0 to 1.0) rather than time-based elapsed.
declarations.title: TransitionState

declarations.comments:
Engine mode determines what happens after a transition completes.

- `Physics`: Force simulation runs, nodes settle via forces
- `Static`: Nodes stay pinned at their final positions
declarations.title: EngineMode

modules.name: Hylograph.Simulation.Core.Types

packageMeta.description: Kernel-agnostic types, interfaces, and orchestration for force simulation
packageMeta.name: purescript-hylograph-simulation-core
